elements.name: QID1
elements.title:
Is eyewitness memory better with Artificial Intelligence?

I would like to invite you to take part in my research project. Before you decide whether to participate, I would like you to understand why the research is being conducted and what it would involve for you. Please email me questions if anything is unclear.

 

What is the purpose of the project?

This project aims to determine if Artificial Intelligence (Face Recognition System) can make a better lineup.

 

Why have I been invited to participate?

We are asking you to take part as we are looking to recruit a diverse sample of people, of any age, gender or ethnicity.

 

Do I have to take part?

It is up to you to decide whether you wish to participate in the project. I will describe the study and you will go through this information sheet before deciding to participate. Please ask any questions you might have. If you agree to take part, you will have to consent. You are free to withdraw at any time, without giving a reason.

 

What will happen to me if I take part and what will I have to do?

You will first watch a brief video (under 1 minute). You may be asked to play some games, like Tetris. Next you will view a police lineup. If you see the person from the video, you will pick that member. If you do not see the person from the video, you will not pick anyone. You will then rate your confidence. The experiment will take less than 10 minutes.

 

What are the possible disadvantages and risks involved in taking part in the project?

There are no known risks in taking part in this experiment. In terms of data collection, no names will be collected, and you will only be identified by a number. We will be in full compliance of GDPR and the standards for data protection set out in the University of Bristol guidelines.

 

What are the possible benefits of taking part?

This research is not designed to help individual participants personally, but the results may help the researchers learn more about eyewitness identification. We hope that, in the future, other people might benefit from this study through improved understanding of human behaviour.

 

Will my participation in this project be kept confidential?

The participation is anonymous, we do not know who the participants are. The data collected about you during the research will be kept strictly confidential. The data will be stored in secure servers. The data may be shared online on sites that are dedicated to hosting anonymised/anonymous data from research.

elements.name: QID16
elements.title:
Now let's play some Tetris!


The Aim in Tetris: Getting all the blocks falling from the top of the screen to fill all the empty space at the bottom of the screen. The blocks will vanish whenever you fill the blank space in a line and you will be awarded points. Your game is over if your pieces reach the top of the screen.


The Rule in Tetris: You can use the left arrow and right arrow to move the blocks around. You can use the up arrow key to rotate them and down arrow key to accelerate their fall.

Set your difficulty levels (default: 5) through the text box at the bottom and click Play/Pause button to score!

elements.name: QID2
elements.title:
Welcome!

 

You are invited to take part in a psychological study at the University of Bristol. Before you agree to take part, please read the following information carefully and ask me if you have any questions.

 

You will not be able to take part on a mobile device.

 

What is the purpose of the study?

This project aims to determine if Artificial Intelligence (Face Recognition System) can make a better lineup.

 

What would taking part involve?

You will first watch a brief video (under 1 minute). You may be asked to play some games, like Tetris. Next you will view a police lineup. If you see the person from the video, you will pick that member. If you do not see the person from the video, you will not pick anyone. You will then rate your confidence.

 

To take part, you:

• must be 18+ years old;

• must be fluent in English.

 

We will ask you to provide some basic demographic information.

The experiment will take less than 10 minutes.

 

Do I have to take part?

It is up to you to decide whether you wish to participate in the project. I will describe the study and you will go through this information sheet before deciding to participate. Please ask any questions you might have. If you agree to take part, you will have to consent. You are free to withdraw at any time, without giving a reason.

 

What happens to the data?

This information will only be available to research staff and national bodies which monitor whether research studies are conducted properly. Your study data will be anonymous. This means that it will be given an identification number and there will be no identifying information about you. Therefore, it will not be possible to identify you by name from any aspect of documentation or reporting for this research study. At the end of the study your data will be stored in an online database so that it is publicly available. This means that the data will be open access.

 

Are there any benefits to taking part and what will happen to the results?

This research is not designed to help individual participants personally, but the results may help the researchers learn more about eyewitness identification. We hope that, in the future, other people might benefit from this study through improved understanding of human behaviour.

 

Who can I contact about the study?

If you have any questions about this study, please ask me now or email me

 

 

General Data Protection Information (GDPR)

Any data you provide during the completion of the study will be stored securely on servers.

 

In place are appropriate technical and organisational security measures to prevent your personal data from being accidentally lost, used or accessed in any unauthorised way or altered or disclosed.

To safeguard your rights, we will use the minimum personally-identifiable information possible (i.e., the email address you provided if you did). The lead researcher will keep your contact details confidential and will use this information only as required (i.e., to provide a summary of the study results if requested and/or for the prize draw). The principal investigator Professor Laura Mickes will keep information about your data gathered from the study for 5 years after the study has finished.

 

Damien Wang and his research collaborators may look at your research records to check the accuracy of the research study. If the study is published in a relevant peer-reviewed journal, the anonymous data may be made available to third parties. The people who analyse the information will not be able to identify you.

 

You can find out more about your rights under the here GDPR and Data Protection Act 2018 .

elements.name: QID20
QID21
elements.title: Timing

elements.name: QID23
elements.title:
Participant Debrief: Is eyewitness memory better with Artificial Intelligence?

 

Thank you for taking part! In this experiment, you saw a video of a mock crime and tried to pick the perpetrator out of a lineup and rated how confident you were. The time you use to make the decision was also recorded.

 

The higher an eyewitness’s confidence in an identification is, the higher the accuracy tends to be. Also, the faster an eyewitness makes an identification, the higher the accuracy tends to be. Therefore, we’ll see if the same holds true with our sample of people who took part.

 

Usually, a police officer will assemble a lineup for eyewitnesses. Lineups include images of the police’s suspect (who may be innocent or guilty) and several other “filler” individuals. Fillers have impacts on memory performance and we are testing whether artificial intelligence, namely, the use of a Face Recognition System, for filler selection leads to higher accuracy in eyewitness identifications. This research could offer critical insights into the efficacy of integrating technology with traditional eyewitness identification procedures, potentially enhancing the reliability of such identifications in criminal justice processes.

 

The results of this research are relevant to the criminal justice system where confidence and time to make decisions in an initial identification of the police suspect from a lineup are just now being considered by the police and courts (in the US, but not yet in the UK). There is much evidence that confidence and time to make decisions in the initial identification of a suspect is indicative of accuracy.

 

If you have any questions or would like to learn more about this research, then please contact Damien Wang .
